item.title: Covid-19: Record day for UK with 711,156 vaccinations given
item.description: More than 26.8 million first and 2.1 million second doses have now been given in the UK since December.

item.title: Covid: Summer holidays abroad 'unlikely', warns government adviser
item.description: There is a risk travellers could bring Covid variants back to the UK, a government adviser warns.

item.title: Covid: France and Poland increase lockdown measures as infections surge
item.description: Some 21 million people in France are affected, while in Poland shops and hotels are shut nationwide.

item.title: Wingate fire: Ex-marine's home destroyed 'after standing up to yobs'
item.description: Sean Ivey believes he was targeted after standing up to anti-social behaviour in his village.

item.title: Covid: Arrests during anti-lockdown protests in London
item.description: Thousands demonstrate in London as police warn of a "significant operation" with 33 arrests so far.

item.title: Walrus spotted in Wales, days after one seen off Ireland
item.description: The RSPCA describe it as "an incredibly rare sighting".

item.title: Iceland volcano: Lava-spewing Fagradalsfjall 'subsiding'
item.description: The eruption was the first in the area for about 800 years and followed thousands of earthquakes.

item.title: Mourners line Tanzania streets at ex-President Magufuli funeral
item.description: The government say Covid-sceptic Magufuli died of heart issues but critics blame coronavirus.

item.title: Elon Musk denies Tesla cars are used for spying in China
item.description: The electric carmaker boss addresses reports of security concerns raised by China's military.

item.title: Uganda: Lions found dead in Queen Elizabeth National Park
item.description: The six lions were found with their heads and paws hacked off, surrounded by dead vultures.

item.title: Late goals take Man City through to FA Cup semi-final
item.description: Late goals from Ilkay Gundogan and Kevin de Bruyne keep Manchester City on course for a quadruple with an FA Cup quarter-final win at Everton.

item.title: Covid-19: Mumbai to roll out compulsory testing in crowded places
item.description: Refusing to be tested in a crowded place will be a criminal offence, city officials say.

item.title: Birmingham's Jewellery Quarter clock 'restored to former glory'
item.description: The chimes of the 118-year-old Jewellery Quarter clock are to ring out for the first time in 30 years.

item.title: The dogs helping endangered Tasmanian devils find a mate
item.description: A world-first trial in Australia is using dogs to help the endangered species procreate.

item.title: Learning Welsh in lockdown... around the world
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic has sparked a rise in people wanting to learn a new language.

item.title: ICYMI: Roof-trotting goats and Super Mario
item.description: From a new Super Mario theme park to some adventurous goats. Some of the stories you may have missed this week.

item.title: Line Of Duty creator Jed Mercurio on the secret of the police drama's success
item.description: As it returns for a sixth series, Line of Duty creator Jed Mercurio says the show owes some of its success to word of mouth.

item.title: White cliffs memorial planned for Dame Vera Lynn
item.description: The singer's family wants to put a sculpture of Dame Vera looking out over the English Channel.

item.title: Thorntons closure: 'It was the place to get that Willy Wonka feeling'
item.description: After 110 years of trading on the high street Thorntons is closing its remaining 61 shops.

item.title: Giving up alcohol: 'I feel like I’ve been reborn’
item.description: Nikki, a recovering alcoholic, describes how she stopped drinking during the pandemic and how it changed her.

item.title: Comic Relief 2021: Justin Bieber and Prince William lead Red Nose Day stars
item.description: And the Duke of Cambridge thanks the public for its "compassion and generosity" as over £45m is raised.

item.title: When is the census and what is it for?
item.description: The once-a-decade survey gives a snapshot of UK life and helps find out what services are needed.

item.title: US President Joe Biden ‘doing fine’ after aircraft stumble
item.description: A spokeswoman said the president is "doing 100% fine" after slipping while boarding Air Force One.

item.title: What happened with the AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: Ros Atkins looks at how a vaccine hailed as a ‘game-changer’ has seen its reputation tarnished.

item.title: Nathan Evans' sea shanty Wellerman goes to number one in UK chart
item.description: Wellerman has gone from 19th Century seafaring song to viral sensation to 2021 chart-topper.

item.title: Why is everyone fighting over the South China Sea?
item.description: China claims most of it but surrounding countries and the US disagree. The BBC's Zhaoyin Feng explains why.

item.title: The Papers: Alarm over Europe's new wave and leaders 'on wanted list'
item.description: Boris Johnson is pictured on several front pages getting a first dose of the Oxford-AstraZeneca jab.

item.title: Viral video exposes inequality in NCAA college basketball
item.description: A widely shared TikTok that contrasted conditions for men and women players has provoked outcry.

item.title: The forgotten referendum of 2011
item.description: Why the referendum everyone's forgotten shaped the last decade of our lives.

item.title: Rachael Blackmore's 'phenomenal' Cheltenham week
item.description: Rachael Blackmore says her Cheltenham Festival was "phenomenal" after becoming the first woman to be the leading jockey at the meeting.

item.title: Skylab: The myth of the mutiny in space
item.description: Did a crew sent to the US Skylab space station go on strike? The last surviving member says it's a myth that won't die.

item.title: Coronavirus: How Russia glosses over its Covid death toll
item.description: The reality behind Russia's pandemic is most likely to be found in its excessive mortality rates.

item.title: Do the Shetland Islands need a tunnel vision?
item.description: Some on the islands are looking to the Faroes for inspiration in tackling transport issues.

item.title: Man's family 'begged' for hospital visit before he died
item.description: David Howells' family were denied access, despite some compassionate hospital visits being allowed.

item.title: Covid-19 leaflets: How pandemic disinformation went offline
item.description: If you thought misleading coronavirus information was just circulating online - think again.

item.title: Ethiopia's Tigray crisis: A rare view inside the conflict zone
item.description: A BBC team gets a glimpse of the human cost of the recent fighting in Tigray.

item.title: Coach Holidays: 'More than a business, we're family'
item.description: Lack of support for "unfashionable" industry could put 24,000 jobs at risk and leave vulnerable passengers heartbroken.

item.title: Wales denied Grand Slam as France score injury-time try to win thriller
item.description: France inflict heartbreak on Wales as they seal victory in dramatic fashion to deny Wayne Pivac's side a Grand Slam in Paris.

item.title: 14-man Ireland thump dismal England
item.description: Ireland produce an outstanding display to overcome an ill-disciplined England 32-18 in the Six Nations despite Bundee Aki's red card.

item.title: Okolie knocks out Glowacki to win world title
item.description: Lawrence Okolie produces a superb display before knocking out Krzysztof Głowacki to become a world champion for the first time.

item.title: Six Nations 2021: France 32-30 Wales highlights
item.description: Watch highlights from a dramatic match as France beat Wales in the dying seconds to end the visitors' Grand Slam hopes and keep alive their chances of winning the Six Nations title.

item.title: FA Cup highlights: Everton 0-2 Manchester City
item.description: Watch highlights as late goals from Ilkay Gundogan and Kevin de Bruyne break Everton resistance at Goodison Park to send Manchester City into the FA Cup semi-finals.

item.title: Covid-19: Have a million people left the UK?
item.description: How far has the UK's foreign-born population fallen during the coronavirus pandemic?

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Wales and Scotland have announced the easing of restrictions on people meeting

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, hairdressers and gyms open?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased, so when will places like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are the latest group to be invited to book their Covid vaccine.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 26 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding and why?
item.description: Shielding in England will end on 31 March.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid-19: EU warns UK over vaccine exports
item.description: The EU threatens to block vaccine exports to the UK unless it "gets its fair share".

item.title: Coronavirus: How are the rules for weddings changing across the UK?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but there are plans to ease the rules.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: The government says it may still be too early to book summer holidays abroad.

item.title: EU plans for a 'vaccine passport' to allow travel
item.description: 'Vaccine passport' plans have been proposed by the EU, in order to make travel easier this summer.

item.title: Covid: When will children return to school and what are the rules?
item.description: Children are returning to school across the UK, after months of enforced home-schooling.

item.title: Lockdown Learning: What educational resources are on TV, iPlayer and online?
item.description: As most pupils return to school, the BBC will continue to offer a wealth of educational material.

item.title: Coronavirus: Data by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: What are the care home rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: What are the new rules for testing and hotel quarantine?
item.description: Travellers going to and from the UK face a growing number of restrictions.

item.title: Am I eligible for the new furlough scheme?
item.description: Furlough has been extended until the end of September.

item.title: Phone scammers: 'Give me £1,000 to stop calling you'
item.description: The rise of scam calls seems relentless - but can anything be done about them?

item.title: So you want a career in building computer games?
item.description: A career in computer games can be rewarding but tough to get into.

item.title: Bedfordshire: Army officer restores WW2 'secret garden' at Chicksands Priory
item.description: The garden at Chicksands Priory was used by code-breakers in World War Two but had been neglected.

item.title: Jed Mercurio: Line of Duty 'still in post-production'
item.description: Line of Duty writer Jed Mercurio says the new series is still not ready, despite airing on Sunday.

item.title: Covid: Lack of contraception sees goats boom in Llandudno
item.description: The Great Orme's goats have not been given their usual contraceptive injection due to the pandemic.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.
